title: H2 - Br2 equilibrium- t9 rates- mole fraction HBr

content.question:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Equimolar amounts of <math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B r 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are injected into an evacuated, rigid container, where they react according to the equation below.

<math alttext="H 2, gas, plus B r 2, gas, are in equilibrium with 2 H B r, gas. Delta H naught for the reaction equals, negative 72.4 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace></mrow><mo>⇄</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><mtext>HBr</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>o</mtext></mrow></msubsup><mtext> </mtext><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>72.4</mn><mtext> kJ/</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) If <math alttext="1.6 grams" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>1.6 g</mtext></mrow></math> of <math alttext="B r 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> is consumed in the reaction with excess <math alttext="H 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, how many moles of <math alttext="H B r" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>HBr</mtext></mrow></math> are produced?

frqParts.text:
Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Equimolar amounts of <math alttext="H 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B r 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are injected into an evacuated, rigid container, where they react according to the equation below.

<math alttext="H 2, gas, plus B r 2, gas, are in equilibrium with 2 H B r, gas. Delta H naught for the reaction equals, negative 72.4 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace></mrow><mo>⇄</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><mtext>HBr</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>o</mtext></mrow></msubsup><mtext> </mtext><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>72.4</mn><mtext> kJ/</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) If <math alttext="1.6 grams" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>1.6 g</mtext></mrow></math> of <math alttext="B r 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> is consumed in the reaction with excess <math alttext="H 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, how many moles of <math alttext="H B r" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>HBr</mtext></mrow></math> are produced?
(b) Which element is reduced in this reaction? Justify your answer in terms of the oxidation numbers.

The partial pressures of the gases in the container are monitored at constant temperature and recorded in the table below.
Time<math alttext="P sub H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>(<math alttext="in atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> )<math alttext="P sub B r 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>(<math alttext="in atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> )<math alttext="P sub H B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>HBr</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></math>(<math alttext="in atmospheres" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> )<math alttext="t sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>1.01.00.0<math alttext="t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>0.780.780.44<math alttext="t sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>0.620.620.76<math alttext="t sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>0.510.510.98<math alttext="t sub 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>0.450.451.10<math alttext="t sub 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>0.420.421.17<math alttext="t sub 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>0.410.411.19<math alttext="t sub 7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>7</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>0.400.401.20<math alttext="t sub 8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>0.400.401.20<math alttext="t sub 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>0.400.401.20
(c) At time <math alttext="t sub 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, is the rate of the forward reaction greater than, less than, or equal to the rate of the reverse reaction? Justify your choice.

(d) At equilibrium, the container holds the most molecules of which gas, <math alttext="H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="B r 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, or <math alttext="H B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>? Explain your answer.

(e) A student hypothesizes that if the temperature of the container is decreased after time <math alttext="t sub 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>9</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, the mole fraction of <math alttext="H B r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HBr</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the container will decrease. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s hypothesis? Justify your answer.

(f) Using the data in the table, determine the value of the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, for the reaction represented by the equation below.

<math alttext="H 2, gas, plus B r 2, gas, are in equilibrium with 2 H B r, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.20em"></mspace></mrow><mo>⇄</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mn>2</mn><mtext> HBr</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

(g) Using the value determined in part (f), determine the value of <math alttext="K sub p, prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>′</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> for the equation shown below.

<math alttext="2 H 2, gas, plus 2 B r 2, gas, are in equilibrium with 4 H B r, gas. K sub p, prime equals question mark." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace></mrow><mo>⇄</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mn>4</mn><mtext> HBr</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>′</mo><mo>=</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><mo>?</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

(h) Which gas, <math alttext="B r 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Br</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="H 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, will behave most like an ideal gas at low temperature? Justify your choice.

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
